awd_titl_txt: Investigations of an invertebrate secreted immune effector that influences microbial communities of the gut
awd_abstract_narration:
The gut of animals is colonized by a rich assortment of microbes and recent research has demonstrated that microbial communities of the gut influence all kinds of physiological processes of the host, from brain function, to development, and obesity.  Hence, understanding the interplay of microbial gut communities and the host is highly important.  The investigators will use Ciona robusta (Ciona intestinalis type A), a marine filter-feeding organism, to investigate how animals use elements of their immune system to regulate healthy interactions with microbes that like to live in the gut.  As Ciona is transparent, it represents a unique model organism in which gut microbial communities can be visualized directly.  Ciona also is a great teaching tool for students in the classroom and for public outreach in the PIs seasonal programs like the St. Petersburg Science Festival or the Oceanography Camp for Girls.  The investigators will utilize animals reared in the lab under controlled conditions to help students understand how distinct microbes colonize the gut, and illustrate natural mechanisms used by animals to influence where and how these microbes settle within the gut. 

Ciona robusta (Ciona intestinalis type A), an invertebrate filter-feeding protochordate, will be used to investigate how the host utilizes elements of innate immunity to negotiate interactions with the gut microbiome.  The proposal focuses on variable immunoglobulin-like chitin-binding proteins (VCBPs).  VCBPs are bifunctional; the N-terminal Ig domains recognize bacteria and the C-terminal domain binds chitin.  VCBPs are a key to understanding complex dialogues between bacteria, fungi and viruses of the gut microbiome.  These proteins are expressed and secreted in high abundance by the gut epithelium in Ciona, and exhibit functions that resemble vertebrate IgA, including the modulation of bacterial adherence and formation of biofilms on mucosal surfaces.  Preliminary data reveal that when VCBP-C binds to some lysogens, induction of prophages is observed, a process that shapes the outcome of biofilm formation and may impact the growth of other bacteria that may be targeted by the newly released phages.  Various bacterial and fungal isolates, derived from the gut of Ciona, have been cultured and will now be studied both in vitro and in vivo utilizing germ-free animals.  This project, via a combination of in vitro and in vivo experiments, will examine the interaction between VCBP-C and cultured isolates (bacterial and fungal) of the gut; we will then examine transcriptomes of in vitro (bacterial) biofilm formation and colonization of germ-free animals to help characterize the genetics of colonization.  As multi-functional proteins, the VCBPs likely bridge interactions between bacterial and fungal communities of the microbiome; and because VCBPs influence the induction of prophages, which in preliminary observations have been shown to possess broad host ranges, it is likely that activation of these viruses can re-shape the composition of the microbiome.  The Ciona model presents a unique opportunity to study how innate immunity not only protects against pathogens but also modulates microbial ecology to achieve and maintain homeostasis.  Ciona will continue to serve as a platform to further explore the hypothesis that immunity evolved not just to "defend" but to "modulate microbial ecology" of the gut lumen.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on Ciona robusta, a type of invertebrate chordate that is an excellent model for studying animal development and immune recognition and defense pathways. It is also being used to study the interactions between hosts and their gut microbiome. This sessile aquatic animal filters water continuously as it feeds, exposing it to constant microbial exchanges across its oral siphon and gut epithelial surfaces. It relies exclusively on innate immunity to protect it from pathogenic threats. It is an important phylogenetic model for understanding how animals can use innate immunity to mediate interactions with microorganisms of the microbiome.

            Ciona from around the world are known to maintain stable microbiomes and viromes. These microbial communities can be compartmentalized in the gut. In the gut, their immune system produces and secretes immunoglobulin-containing effector proteins called VCBPs, that bind bacteria, enhance clearance, and impact the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. They also bind diverse fungi through their C-terminal chitin-binding domain (CBD). Moreover, CBD domains help anchor the proteins to the chitin-rich mucus lining the gut and the pharynx of Ciona. Thus, we hypothesize that VCBPs are helping shape the structure and function of the microbiome. This project aimed to investigate this hypothesis in greater depth. 

Via the CBD, VCBP-C not only binds diverse fungi but has an important influence on how they grow and spread. Over the course of this project, we developed co-culture approaches and bacterial-fungal pair-wise combinations with or without VCBP, revealing important influences of the VCBP proteins (Natarajan, Liberti, et al, in preparation). Unbiased transcriptome data (RNAseq) during colonization of the juvenile gut, revealed an exciting interplay between VCBP-C and VCBP-D, the latter of which we had not studied in detail. VCBP-D is similar to VCBP-C but lacks a CBD; thus its role in the gut lumen reveals an important interplay shaping the outcome of colonization events.

Furthermore, this project included efforts that resulted in an improved understanding of the role (and impact) of strain variants in the gut of animals. This part of the gut microbiome in animals does not receive enough attention, but microbes, like bacteria, undergo strain variation when stressed, including dietary changes. These variants can result from changes to the DNA, e.g., mutation, but can also be non-mutational. The latter are usually reversible and produce unique morphotypes, or bacterial isolates that behave very differently and often produce different surface products making them unique. Strain variants can mediate functional influences in the microbiome of animals but often remain invisible in typical microbiome studies. 

We identified and isolated diverse bacterial species from the Ciona gut, i.e., focusing on native isolates and strain variants. One type of variant is infected by a bacteriophage (a virus that infects bacteria). The virus replicates and eventually bursts from the cell, releasing many copies of itself. However, sometimes the virus infects and integrates its DNA into the bacterial DNA, and remains dormant until awoken by an external stressor to escape via the lytic pathway. Because their integration can disrupt some genes, or their own DNA can carry regulatory regions or antibiotic resistance genes, there is growing evidence that this accessory genome can exert biological changes in the bacteria, e.g., how it behaves, its metabolic preferences, or its virulence. The integration of prophages can contribute to strain variation.  

We focused on two species native to the Ciona gut, Shewanella fidelis 3313 and a Pseudoalteromonas species 6751, and identified morphotype variants and biological variation mediated by prophages. We established prophage knockout substrains to study the impact of the individual prophages and found evidence that the viral accessory genome is likely impacting these biological traits by influencing the production of secondary messengers like cyclic di-nucleotides. But most surprisingly, we found that colonization of these variants into the Ciona model system revealed an unanticipated immune specificity; the Ciona immune system could perceive and respond to these variants with unique immune profiles (Natarajan et al, BioRxiv 2022; Natarajan et al, in preparation). These investigations leveraged the Ciona model, which is making important contributions to microbiome science as a system with rapid generation times, known genetics, transparent juveniles attached to dishes (in vivo observation), and a system to investigate the influence of host genetic diversity.

This project integrated research and education and focused on broadening participation in the cross-disciplinary fields of microbial ecology, development, and immunology. We incorporated unique microbial ecology modules into the USF Oceanography Camp for Girls, a 6-week summer camp that provides extensive laboratory exposure for middle school STEM participants. This project received an REU supplement and hosted a student from Spelman University. Additionally, our OCG efforts inspired a student high school student who returned for two additional summers to intern in our lab. Participating students made and presented displays to present their research experience and, also submitted a final report to their teachers.
